name: Dresden
fun_fact: Fun fact: Dresden's famous Christstollen (Christmas bread) is so culturally important that it has Protected Geographical Indication status - only stollen made within Dresden's city limits can use the official seal, and the annual Stollenfest features a parade with a giant 4-ton stollen cake.

hero_dishes.name: SÃ¤chsischer Sauerbraten
hero_dishes.description: Saxon-style pot roast marinated for days in vinegar, red wine, and herbs, then slow-cooked until fork-tender. The Saxon version is slightly sweeter than other German regions.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Saxony's take on Germany's national dish adds fruit or sugar to the marinade, creating a distinctive sweet-savory profile. Originally a way to preserve and tenderize tough cuts of meat, it became a symbol of Saxon culinary pride.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Sophienkeller (medieval atmosphere with vaulted ceilings), Dresden 1900 (part of 'Train Conductor's Pan')

hero_dishes.name: Quarkkeulchen
hero_dishes.description: Pan-fried potato pancakes made with quark cheese, boiled potatoes, and raisins. Served sweet with cinnamon sugar and applesauce, or savory with mushrooms.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A uniquely Saxon dish that straddles sweet and savory. The use of quark (a fresh cheese) and potatoes reflects Saxon resourcefulness, while the dual preparation shows the region's culinary creativity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Found at cafes throughout Dresden, GÃ¤nsedieb (home-style Saxon cuisine)

hero_dishes.name: Eierschecke
hero_dishes.description: Three-layer sheet cake with yeast dough base, quark cheese middle, and vanilla pudding custard top. Sometimes with apples, poppy seeds, or raisins.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Saxon cafÃ© staple found throughout Dresden year-round. The name means 'egg corner,' and it's been a Dresden specialty for generations. Each bakery has their own recipe variation.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Found at most cafÃ©s and coffee houses throughout Dresden, traditional bakeries

hero_dishes.name: Crispy Pork Knuckle at Altmarktkeller
hero_dishes.description: Slow-roasted pork knuckle with crackling skin, served with sauerkraut and potato dumplings.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Served in the historic beer hall Altmarktkeller with stunning vaulted ceilings. The Saxon preparation emphasizes getting the skin impossibly crispy while keeping the meat tender and juicy.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Altmarktkeller (historic beer hall in Altmarkt district, renowned for regional craft brews)

signature_drinks.name: Saxon Pilsner
signature_drinks.description: Regional craft beers from Saxon breweries, typically crisp and hoppy pilsners.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed in historic beer halls like Altmarktkeller and Pulverturm. Locals take their beer seriously, favoring regional breweries over mass-market brands.

signature_drinks.name: Radeberger Pilsner
signature_drinks.description: Germany's most famous export pilsner, brewed just outside Dresden in Radeberg since 1872.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The local pride beer - while it's sold worldwide, drinking it in Dresden connects you to Saxon brewing tradition. Served cold in traditional beer hall steins.

food_culture_notes: Dresden's food scene blends baroque-era recipes with contemporary presentations - staff in historic costumes serve traditional dishes
The Sachsenmarkt (Saxon Market) every Friday is where locals buy fresh regional products - 160 stalls of authentic Saxon ingredients
Many restaurants occupy historic buildings - powder towers from 1565, medieval vaults, baroque palaces
Dresdner Christstollen is only sold November-December, making it a seasonal pilgrimage for locals and tourists
